message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest alcoholic hepatitis, which can cause Mallory-Denk bodies to form in the liver. Florid bile duct lesion is seen in primary biliary cholangitis, steatosis alone may be seen in non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, and Hürthle cells are associated with thyroid tumors, not liver disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's history of alcohol consumption and clinical findings suggest alcoholic hepatitis. Mallory-Denk bodies are characteristic of alcoholic hepatitis on liver biopsy. Florid bile duct lesions are seen in primary biliary cirrhosis, steatosis alone can be seen in non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, and Hürthle cells are associated with thyroid disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history of heavy alcohol use and elevated liver enzymes suggest alcoholic liver disease. Mallory-Denk bodies, which are eosinophilic inclusion bodies, are commonly seen in alcoholic hepatitis. Florid bile duct lesion is seen in primary biliary cholangitis, and Hürthle cells are typically seen in thyroid neoplasms. Steatosis alone is a common feature of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is presenting with symptoms of alcoholic hepatitis, which is characterized by inflammation and necrosis of hepatocytes. Mallory-Denk bodies, which are eosinophilic protein aggregates, are a hallmark of alcoholic hepatitis and can be seen on liver biopsy. 'Florid' bile duct lesions are more commonly associated with primary sclerosing cholangitis, while Hürthle cells are seen in thyroid tumors. Steatosis alone may be seen in non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, but in this case, the patient has a history of heavy alcohol consumption.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with signs suggestive of alcoholic hepatitis, given his heavy alcohol consumption and elevated liver enzymes. Mallory-Denk bodies, which are eosinophilic proteinaceous inclusions in hepatocytes, are a characteristic finding in alcoholic hepatitis on liver biopsy. The other options are not typically seen in alcoholic hepatitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s presentation is consistent with alcoholic liver disease. Mallory-Denk bodies are eosinophilic accumulations of protein found in hepatocytes and are a common finding in alcoholic liver disease. 'Florid' bile duct lesion is a characteristic finding of primary biliary cirrhosis, which is not likely in this patient. Steatosis alone or Hürthle cells would not be specific findings for alcoholic liver disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's history and laboratory values suggest alcohol-induced liver damage, and Mallory-Denk bodies are commonly seen in cases of alcoholic hepatitis. 'Florid' bile duct lesion is seen in primary biliary cirrhosis, steatosis alone may be seen in non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, and Hürthle cells are associated with thyroid neoplasms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of alcohol-related liver disease, which can lead to the formation of Mallory-Denk bodies in the liver. 'Florid' bile duct lesion is associated with primary biliary cirrhosis and Hürthle cells are associated with thyroid cancer. Steatosis alone may be seen in non-alcoholic fatty liver disease but is less likely in this patient who has a significant alcohol history.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history and laboratory findings suggest alcoholic hepatitis, and among the options, only Mallory-Denk bodies are associated with this disease. Steatosis alone is common in alcoholic liver disease but is not specific for alcoholic hepatitis. Florid bile duct lesion is seen in primary sclerosing cholangitis, and Hürthle cells are associated with thyroid disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest alcoholic hepatitis, which is frequently associated with Mallory-Denk bodies, which are abnormal structures found in liver cells. A "florid" bile duct lesion is associated with primary biliary cirrhosis, which is not suggested by the patient’s history. Steatosis alone is not likely to cause the patient’s symptoms, and Hürthle cells are associated with thyroid nodules, not liver disease.
